definition: to fall down/to take a fall
to fall/to tumble/to trip/(of prices etc) to drop/Taiwan pr. [die2]
a tumble/a fall

sentences.english: He that never climbed never fell.
sentences.chinese: 只有不攀登的人才不会跌跤。

sentences.english: Error is often the precursor of what is correct, but conceit is the prelude to a fall.
sentences.chinese: 错误往往是正确的先导，骄傲是跌跤的前奏。

sentences.english: The old man disjointed his knee when he fell.
sentences.chinese: 老人跌跤时把膝关节摔脱了臼。

sentences.english: A child who has just learnt to walk can fall down even on level and smooth ground.
sentences.chinese: 刚刚会走路的小孩子在平正的地面上仍会跌跤。

sentences.english: The toddler tried to walk but kept falling down.
sentences.chinese: 那小孩学着走路但老是跌跤。

sentences.english: The physics prize went to a study of why pregnant women don’t tip over. Usually.
sentences.chinese: 物理学奖授予一项探求孕妇为什么不跌跤的科学研究。

sentences.english: He caught his foot on a tree root and stumbled.
sentences.chinese: 他一只脚被树根绊住而跌跤了。

definition: variant of 跌跤[die1 jiao1]
to tumble/to fall/fig. to suffer a reverse (in politics or business)
to fall down/to slip and fall/to throw sb to the ground
to take a fall
to injure oneself in a fall
a tumble/a fall
to walk/to go on foot
to fall and fracture (a leg, vertebra etc)
to stumble over sth
lame
to trip/to stumble
to fall flat on one's face (vulgar)
to fall flat on one's face
paralysis of one side of the body/hemiplegia
high, lofty/precipitous
to sprain (one's ankle)/see 崴子[wai3 zi5]
legs and feet/ability to walk/strides
